facts.text: These are 44 civil appeals by certificate from the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 40-46,48- 68, 70-74 and 76-86 of 1966. Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 2,1955 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 96, 281, 303, 836, 1029, 1130, 1219 and 1497 of 1963, and 79, 94, 1 1 1, 112, 141, 142, 148, 149, 159, 167, 171, 172, 173, 183,256,267,286,443,491,497,549,571,591,611,616,680,695,700, 720, 725, 737, 760, 1148, 1464 and 1789 of 1964 respectively.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court delivered a common judgment on September 2, 1955 allowing writ petitions under Art. 226.
High Court directed State of Andhra Pradesh and authorities to forbear from collecting land revenue assessment under Principal Act as amended.

anchor.surface_text: These 44 appeals by certificate are preferred against the companymon judgment of a Division Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court allowing the petitions filed by the respondents under Art. 226 of the Constitution for directing the State of Andhra Pradesh and other appropriate authorities to forbear from companylecting the assessment of land revenue under the provisions of the Andhra Pradesh Land Revenue  Additional Assessment  and Cess Revision Act, 1962  Act 22 of 1962 , hereinafter called the Principal Act, as amended by the Andhra Pradesh Land Revenue  Additional Assessment  and Cess Revision  Amendment  Act, 1962  Act 23 of 1962 , hereinafter called the Amending Act.

facts.text: Principal Act (Act 22 of 1962) passed on September 27, 1962 and came into force on July 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Principal Act was passed on September 27, 1962 and it came into force on July 1, 1962 and the Amending Act was passed on December 24, 1962, and it came into force on July 1, 1962.

facts.text: Amending Act (Act 23 of 1962) passed on December 24, 1962 and came into force on July 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Principal Act was passed on September 27, 1962 and it came into force on July 1, 1962 and the Amending Act was passed on December 24, 1962, and it came into force on July 1, 1962.

facts.text: Object of Principal Act was to rationalize land revenue assessment by uniformity between Telangana and Andhra areas, raise rates due to price rise, equitable burden on ryots.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the main object in passing the Principal Act was to rationalize the land revenue assessment in the State by bringing uniformity between Telengana and Andhra areas and to raise the rate of revenue in view of the rise in prices and to make the ryots bear equitably their share of the burden of the plans.

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act levies additional assessment of 75% on dry land, minimum 50 naye paise per acre per fasli year.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3. In case of dry land in the State, an additional assessment at the rate of seventy-five per cent of the assessment payable for a fasli year for that land shall be levied and companylected by the Government from the person liable to pay the assessment for each fasli year in respect of that land Provided that the additional assessment together with the assessment payable in respect of any such land shall in numbercase be less than fifty naye paise per acre per fasli year.

facts.text: Section 4 of the Act levies additional assessment of 100% or 50% on wet land based on Government irrigation source class in Table.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4. In the case of wet land in the State which Is served by a Government source of irrigation specified in classes 1, II, and III of the Table below, an additional assessment at the rate of one hundred per cent and in the case of wet land in the State which is served by a Government source of irrigation specified in Class IV thereof, an additional assessment at the rate of fifty per cent, of the assessment payable for a fasli year for that land shall be levied and companylected by the Government from the person liable to pay the assessment for each fasli year in respect of that land

facts.text: Classification under Section 4 Table based on extent of ayacut: Class I 30,000+ acres, II 5,000-30,000, III 50-5,000, IV below 50.

facts.text: High Court found no classification for dry lands under S.3, ayacut basis under S.4 has no rational relation to taram or quality.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in deciding against the companystitutional validity of the said provisions gave in effect the following findings  1  Under s. 3 of the Act there is numberclassification at all in the case of dry lands.  2  The ayacut basis adopted in the Table under S. 4 of the Act has numberrational relation to the taram or quality of the land or the nature of the irrigation source.

facts.text: High Court held Act silent on machinery for assessment, criteria, rights of assessees.

anchor.surface_text: 4  The Act is silent as to the machinery for making the assessment, the criteria for fixation of the assessment, within the range of a fixed maximum and a minimum the rights and remedies of the assesses and the obligation of the Government to survey the lands.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Sections 3 and 4 offend Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, therefore, clearly offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Ryotwari Settlement introduced in 1865 based on survey and soil classification.

anchor.surface_text: After some experiments in the Madras State it was decided in 1865 that a general revision of assessment should be made based on accurate survey and classification of soils. This is known as Ryotwari Settlement.

facts.text: Ryotwari Settlements abandoned in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Ryotwari Settlements were abandoned in the year 1939.

facts.text: Land Revenue Reforms Committee appointed by Government of Andhra Pradesh in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1958 the Government of Andhra Pradesh appointed Land Revenue Reforms Committee to examine the existing system and rates of land revenue assessment and irrigation charges obtaining in the various regions of the State and to make suitable recommendations for their rationalisation.

facts.text: Previous assessments based on taram in Andhra and bhagana in Telangana reflecting soil quality and productivity.

anchor.surface_text: land assessment, both in Andhra and in Telengana, was scientifically settled on the basis of taram or bhagana, as the case may be, depending upon the quality and the productivity of the soil

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: District Collector specifies Government sources of irrigation by notification under Section 8(1), appeal to Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8.  1  The District Collector, shall, from time to time, by numberification published in the Andhra Pradesh Gazette and the District Gazette, specify the Government sources of irrigation falling under classes 1, 11 and IV of the Table under section 4 and may in like manner, include in, or exclude from, such numberification any such source. Any person aggrieved by a numberification published under subsection  1  may, within forty-five days from the date of publication of the numberification in the Andhra Pradesh Gazette and the District Gazette, prefer an appeal to the Board of Revenue whose decision thereon shall be final.

facts.text: Section 6 treats additional assessment as land revenue for all purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6. The additional assessment payable under this Act in respect of any land shall, for all purposes, be treated as land revenue.

facts.text: No procedure for assessment prescribed in the Act apart from S.6.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if S. 6 is put aside, there is absolutely numberprovision in the Act prescribing the mode of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Decided cases laid down two tests to ascertain whether a classification is permissible or not, viz., (i) the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: The High Court went wrong in concluding that the revenue assessment made under the Act had no reasonable relation to the quality of the soil; what the Legislature did was nothing more than imposing a surcharge on previous rates fixed on the basis of tarams in Andhra and bhagana in Telangana

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. V. Gupte, learned Solicitor General, who appeared in one of the appeals filed by the State, contended broadly that the High Court went wrong in coming to the conclusion that the revenue assessment made under the Act had no reasonable relation to the quality of the soil and pointed out that what the Legislature did was nothing more than imposing a surcharge on previous rates fixed on the basis of tarams in the case of lands in Andhra and bhagana in the case of lands in Telengana.

arguments.claim: Though the classification under S. 4 of the Act was apparently based upon ayacut, there was a correlation between the extent of the ayacut and the duration of water supply and that on that basis the classification could be sustained as it had a reasonable relation to taram or bhagana and also to the duration of water supply

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. Ram Reddy, learned counsel for the State in the other appeals, while adopting the arguments of the learned Solicitor General, argued in greater detail contending that though the classification under S. 4. of the Act was apparently based upon ayacut, there was a correlation between the extent of the ayacut and the duration of water supply and that on that basis the classification could be sustained as it had a reasonable relation to taram or bhagana, as the case may be, and also to the duration of water supply.

arguments.claim: From time immemorial land assessment, both in Andhra and in Telangana, was scientifically settled on the basis of taram or bhagana depending upon the quality and the productivity of the soil; the Act ignores that and adopts arbitrary ayacut method

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. A. Chowdhury, learned counsel for some of the respondents, argued that from time immemorial land assessment, both in Andhra and in Telengana, was scientifically settled on the basis of taram or bhagana, as the case may be, depending upon the quality and the productivity of the soil and that the Act in adopting the maximum and the minimum rates in respect of both dry and wet lands had ignored the said basis and instead adopted a thoroughly arbitrary method of fixing rates on the basis of ayacut which had no relevance at all to the quality or productivity of the land

arguments.claim: Sections 3 and 4 do not offend Art.14 as they pass reasonable classification test: intelligible differentia (surcharge on prior rates/ayacut correlating to water duration) with rational nexus to rationalization object

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts the question is whether ss. 3 and 4 of the Act offend Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The Act clearly offends Art.14 due to lack of reasonable classification (no intelligible differentia between dry/wet lands based on soil; ayacut unrelated to productivity/water duration) and arbitrary procedure (no assessment machinery)

anchor.surface_text: The Act, therefore, clearly offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Official arbitrariness (lack of procedure) more subversive of equality than statutory discrimination; Act confers uncanalized power violating Art.14

anchor.surface_text: Official arbitrariness is more subversive of the doctrine of equality than statutory discrimination. In respect of a statutory discrimination one knows where he stands, but the wand of official arbitrariness can be waved in all directions indiscriminately.

arguments.claim: Twin test for classification under Art.14: (i) intelligible differentia distinguishing grouped from others; (ii) rational relation to object

anchor.surface_text: Decided cases laid down two tests to ascertain whether a classification is permissible or not, viz., (i) the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala apply: flat rate tax without regard to productivity violates Art.14

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The State of Kerala held that the Travancore-Cochin Land Tax Act, 1955, infringed Art. 14 of the Constitution, as it obliged every person who held land to pay the tax at the flat rate prescribed, whether or not he made any income out of the property

arguments.claim: Madras and Mysore surcharge Acts distinguished: those were additions to scientific prior rates; here entire scheme changed to arbitrary flat/ayacut basis

anchor.surface_text: Two decisions relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellant may not be noticed. In C. V. Rajagopalachariar v. State of Madras the facts were two Acts... were passed... increasing the land revenue... on the basis of ryotwari settlements which did not offend Art. 14

holdings.text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Act offend Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, therefore, clearly offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification under ss.3&4 lacks intelligible differentia based on soil quality/productivity and rational nexus to rationalization object; ayacut unrelated to water duration; no assessment machinery leads to official arbitrariness.

holdings.text: There is no classification at all under Section 3 for dry lands; flat minimum rate irrespective of soil quality.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of the Act there is no classification at all in the case of dry lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3 imposes 75% additional on prior assessment with minimum 50 np/acre regardless of taram/soil fertility, ignoring historical ryotwari classification.

holdings.text: Ayacut basis under Section 4 has no rational relation to taram, soil quality, or irrigation duration.

anchor.surface_text: Enough has been said to make the point that classification based on ayacut has no reasonable relation to the duration of water supply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statistical average/majority tests fail; counterexamples show no correlation between ayacut extent and water supply months or productivity; tanks with similar duration in different classes.

holdings.text: The Act contains no machinery/procedure for assessment, criteria, notice, or remedies.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if S. 6 is put aside, there is absolutely no provision in the Act prescribing the mode of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ss.3&4 are charging sections without designating officer, notice, survey obligation, or appeal on assessment; S.8 only for irrigation classification.

holdings.text: Section 6 does not incorporate Standing Orders of Board of Revenue or prior assessment procedures.

anchor.surface_text: This argument has been pitched rather high and we do not think that the phraseology of the section permits any such interpretation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.6 treats additional assessment as land revenue for recovery post-assessment; does not address pre-assessment machinery or incorporate by reference.
